title: Experts warn Prince Harry’s memoir re-release could reignite royal feud
content: Prince Harry's memoir, Spare, is set for a paperback release on October 24, the same day as King Charles's Commonwealth summit in Samoa. Royal experts are concerned this timing could revive tensions within the family. The release, without new content, may attract more readers, potentially overshadowing the King's commitments and reigniting controversy.
summary: Prince Harry's memoir, Spare, is set for a paperback release on October 24, the same day as King Charles's Commonwealth summit in Samoa. Royal experts are concerned this timing could revive tensions within the family. The release, without new content, may attract more readers, potentially overshadowing the King's commitments and reigniting controversy.

title: Florida sheriff slams Washington DC lawmakers after illegal immigrants arrested for $7,300 palmetto berry theft
content: Last week, eight individuals, including four illegal immigrants, were arrested in Florida for allegedly stealing $7,300 worth of palmetto berries. The suspects loaded around 9,000 pounds of berries into a U-Hau. Brevard County Sheriff Wayne Ivey publicly criticised Washington DC lawmakers for their failure to enforce border security, emphasising that illegal immigration leads to further crimes. Ivey noted that some suspects had previously been deported and expressed frustration over the inability to deport individuals with pending court dates or nonviolent crimes.
summary: Last week, eight individuals, including four illegal immigrants, were arrested in Florida for allegedly stealing $7,300 worth of palmetto berries. The suspects loaded around 9,000 pounds of berries into a U-Hau. Brevard County Sheriff Wayne Ivey publicly criticised Washington DC lawmakers for their failure to enforce border security, emphasising that illegal immigration leads to further crimes. Ivey noted that some suspects had previously been deported and expressed frustration over the inability to deport individuals with pending court dates or nonviolent crimes.

title: Former Neveda politician Robert Telles convicted of murdering Las Vegas journalist
content: Former county official Robert Telles has been convicted of murdering veteran journalist Jeff German after German published articles critical of him. The incident occurred in September 2022, outside German's home. Despite Telles's claims of being framed, DNA and video evidence implicated him. The jury's decision is seen as justice for German, who spent his career addressing issues like political corruption. The case highlights the peril journalists face while holding officials accountable.
summary: Former county official Robert Telles has been convicted of murdering veteran journalist Jeff German after German published articles critical of him. The incident occurred in September 2022, outside German's home. Despite Telles's claims of being framed, DNA and video evidence implicated him. The jury's decision is seen as justice for German, who spent his career addressing issues like political corruption. The case highlights the peril journalists face while holding officials accountable.

title: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov charged in France for alleged criminal activity on platform
content: French investigative judges have charged Telegram CEO Pavel Durov, a French citizen, with preliminary offenses related to criminal activities on his messaging app. Durov faces allegations of enabling child sexual abuse material and drug trafficking while obstructing investigations. Durov had co-founded Telegram with his brother after facing pressure from Russian authorities
summary: French investigative judges have charged Telegram CEO Pavel Durov, a French citizen, with preliminary offenses related to criminal activities on his messaging app. Durov faces allegations of enabling child sexual abuse material and drug trafficking while obstructing investigations. Durov had co-founded Telegram with his brother after facing pressure from Russian authorities

title: US supreme court declines to lift block on Biden’s student loan repayment plan
content: The US supreme court has decided against lifting the block on President Biden's student loan repayment plan. The plan, paused due to legal challenges, would lower monthly payments and expedite loan forgiveness. Borrowers in the SAVE program are currently in interest-free forbearance, while the legal proceedings continue in lower courts to determine the plan's future.
summary: The US supreme court has decided against lifting the block on President Biden's student loan repayment plan. The plan, paused due to legal challenges, would lower monthly payments and expedite loan forgiveness. Borrowers in the SAVE program are currently in interest-free forbearance, while the legal proceedings continue in lower courts to determine the plan's future.

title: Trump shooter spent months searching for target before choosing him, reveals FBI
content: The FBI disclosed that Thomas Crooks, 20, attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a July rally in Pennsylvania after extensive research on both Trump and Biden. Nearly 1,000 interviews were conducted, but Crooks' motive remains unclear. Authorities highlighted his mixed ideologies and focus on opportunistic targets. An FBI official said that the suspected shooter exhibited a mix of ideologies and did not align strictly with either right-leaning or left-leaning views.
summary: The FBI disclosed that Thomas Crooks, 20, attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a July rally in Pennsylvania after extensive research on both Trump and Biden. Nearly 1,000 interviews were conducted, but Crooks' motive remains unclear. Authorities highlighted his mixed ideologies and focus on opportunistic targets. An FBI official said that the suspected shooter exhibited a mix of ideologies and did not align strictly with either right-leaning or left-leaning views.

title: Community raise $20,000 after health department shutsdown 12-year-old's ice cream stand
content: Twelve-year-old Danny Doherty set up an ice cream stand to raise funds for his brother’s hockey team but was ordered to close by the Norwood Board of Health for violating food regulations. The community rallied in support, resulting in Danny raising $20,000 for the Boston Bear Cubs, a team for players with disabilities. Nancy Thrasher, co-owner of Furlong’s Candies, explained that Danny was trying to do something good for his brother’s team, emphasizing that it wasn’t just any regular hockey team.
summary: Twelve-year-old Danny Doherty set up an ice cream stand to raise funds for his brother’s hockey team but was ordered to close by the Norwood Board of Health for violating food regulations. The community rallied in support, resulting in Danny raising $20,000 for the Boston Bear Cubs, a team for players with disabilities. Nancy Thrasher, co-owner of Furlong’s Candies, explained that Danny was trying to do something good for his brother’s team, emphasizing that it wasn’t just any regular hockey team.

title: Vivek Ramaswamy reveals he asked Mark Zuckeberg to apologise about 'censorship'
content: Entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy advised Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg to publicly acknowledge past mistakes, particularly banning Trump, to aid national healing in an old interview. Trump disclosed Zuckerberg apologized for censoring his photo. Roivant Sciences founder recalled how he questioned Zuckerberg during a UFC 300 event on the broader implications of societal censorship, particularly in the realm of speech.
summary: Entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy advised Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg to publicly acknowledge past mistakes, particularly banning Trump, to aid national healing in an old interview. Trump disclosed Zuckerberg apologized for censoring his photo. Roivant Sciences founder recalled how he questioned Zuckerberg during a UFC 300 event on the broader implications of societal censorship, particularly in the realm of speech.

title: At least nine Palestinians killed as Israel mounts major West Bank operation
Indiana man admits poisoning wife's Coca-Cola to marry her daughter
content: Alfred Ruf, a 71-year-old man, admitted to poisoning his wife's Coca-Cola with a toxic substance to kill her and marry her daughter. He pleaded guilty to aggravated battery and was sentenced to four years in prison and five years of probation. The wife tested positive for drugs and reported him to the authorities. ​​​​Ruf explained that the daughter and a female friend would instruct him to spike his wife’s drink, and then they would visit his home to add more of the substance to the drink while she slept.
summary: Alfred Ruf, a 71-year-old man, admitted to poisoning his wife's Coca-Cola with a toxic substance to kill her and marry her daughter. He pleaded guilty to aggravated battery and was sentenced to four years in prison and five years of probation. The wife tested positive for drugs and reported him to the authorities. ​​​​Ruf explained that the daughter and a female friend would instruct him to spike his wife’s drink, and then they would visit his home to add more of the substance to the drink while she slept.

title: Afghan women filmed singing in protest of ban on their voices
content: Afghan women are protesting an online Taliban law that bans them from raising their voices in public. The new regulation mandates that women must cover their faces, bodies, and voices when outside their homes. Many women, from inside and outside Afghanistan, are defying this law by posting videos of themselves singing on social media.
summary: Afghan women are protesting an online Taliban law that bans them from raising their voices in public. The new regulation mandates that women must cover their faces, bodies, and voices when outside their homes. Many women, from inside and outside Afghanistan, are defying this law by posting videos of themselves singing on social media.

title: South Korea to ask Telegram, other social media firms to help tackle digital sex crimes
content: South Korean authorities are pushing Telegram and other social media platforms to aid in the removal of sexually explicit deepfake content. They plan to set up a 24-hour hotline and increase the number of regulatory personnel. The Korea Communications Standards Commission intends to collaborate directly with social media firms for better content moderation.
summary: South Korean authorities are pushing Telegram and other social media platforms to aid in the removal of sexually explicit deepfake content. They plan to set up a 24-hour hotline and increase the number of regulatory personnel. The Korea Communications Standards Commission intends to collaborate directly with social media firms for better content moderation.

title: California start-up aims to 'sell sunlight' at night; see video
content: California-based startup Reflect Orbital plans to extend solar energy availability by reflecting sunlight onto solar panels at night using satellites equipped with mylar mirrors. CEO Ben Nowack presented this innovation at an energy conference in London. The first launch is scheduled for 2025, promising to bridge the energy gap and enhance solar power utilization globally.
summary: California-based startup Reflect Orbital plans to extend solar energy availability by reflecting sunlight onto solar panels at night using satellites equipped with mylar mirrors. CEO Ben Nowack presented this innovation at an energy conference in London. The first launch is scheduled for 2025, promising to bridge the energy gap and enhance solar power utilization globally.

title: Indian students in Canada protest new immigration policies amid deportation fears
content: Indian students in Canada are protesting new immigration policies announced by Prime Minister Trudeau’s government. Over 70,000 international students are affected by restrictions on study permits and a reduction in permanent residency nominations. Concerns about deportation and financial instability have grown, with students feeling misled. Temporary foreign worker numbers are also being reduced.
summary: Indian students in Canada are protesting new immigration policies announced by Prime Minister Trudeau’s government. Over 70,000 international students are affected by restrictions on study permits and a reduction in permanent residency nominations. Concerns about deportation and financial instability have grown, with students feeling misled. Temporary foreign worker numbers are also being reduced.

title: Mark Zuckerberg's leaked video resurfaces amidst censorship accusations: What's the real story?
Find empty shelves of rice in Japan's supermarkets. What are the causes behind this
content: Japan is seeing a rice shortage, with supermarket shelves emptying due to government warnings of a potential megaquake and typhoons. Hot weather has impacted harvests, but the Ministry of Agriculture assures that the situation will improve as new rice is released. Consumers are urged to avoid panic buying and to purchase only necessary amounts.
summary: Japan is seeing a rice shortage, with supermarket shelves emptying due to government warnings of a potential megaquake and typhoons. Hot weather has impacted harvests, but the Ministry of Agriculture assures that the situation will improve as new rice is released. Consumers are urged to avoid panic buying and to purchase only necessary amounts.

title: THIS airline accidentally sells first-class seats for pennies — Here’s what happened next
content: Qantas is addressing a major pricing blunder that led to the sale of first-class tickets at significantly reduced rates. The airline offers affected passengers either a rebooking into business class or a refund. This comes after a recent fine for selling tickets on canceled flights. Customers and observers are closely watching Qantas' response.
summary: Qantas is addressing a major pricing blunder that led to the sale of first-class tickets at significantly reduced rates. The airline offers affected passengers either a rebooking into business class or a refund. This comes after a recent fine for selling tickets on canceled flights. Customers and observers are closely watching Qantas' response.

title: United Airlines faces criticism over flight attendant’s Palestinian flag pin: How company responds amid growing backlash
content: A United Airlines flight attendant's display of a Palestinian flag pin and keffiyeh during a flight from Chicago to Newark has drawn criticism. While pro-Israel advocates argue such symbols should be off-duty, the airline maintains its policy permitting flag pins to indicate language skills or personal pride, fostering a broader discussion on political symbols at work.
summary: A United Airlines flight attendant's display of a Palestinian flag pin and keffiyeh during a flight from Chicago to Newark has drawn criticism. While pro-Israel advocates argue such symbols should be off-duty, the airline maintains its policy permitting flag pins to indicate language skills or personal pride, fostering a broader discussion on political symbols at work.

title: Is Barron Trump’s college decision in flux? Absence of him and his security at orientation raises questions
content: Last week, former President Donald Trump revealed that his son, Barron Trump, will attend a university in New York, deviating from the family's Ivy League tradition. While the school remains undisclosed, Trump cited campus unrest as a factor in the decision. Barron's academic excellence and campus involvement have been praised, adding intrigue.
summary: Last week, former President Donald Trump revealed that his son, Barron Trump, will attend a university in New York, deviating from the family's Ivy League tradition. While the school remains undisclosed, Trump cited campus unrest as a factor in the decision. Barron's academic excellence and campus involvement have been praised, adding intrigue.

title: One cigarette butt and DNA match: How police decoded decades-old murder mystery
content: DNA evidence from a cigarette butt has led to the arrest of 65-year-old Kenneth Kundert for the 1980 rape and murder of Boeing instructor Dorothy Silzel in Kent, Washington. New forensic genealogy technology identified Kundert among potential suspects. He was apprehended following a joint effort with Arkansas authorities and will face charges upon extradition to Washington.
summary: DNA evidence from a cigarette butt has led to the arrest of 65-year-old Kenneth Kundert for the 1980 rape and murder of Boeing instructor Dorothy Silzel in Kent, Washington. New forensic genealogy technology identified Kundert among potential suspects. He was apprehended following a joint effort with Arkansas authorities and will face charges upon extradition to Washington.
